questions.question: What is 'Proper Time' ($\Delta t_0$)?
options: Time as measured by a perfectly synchronized atomic clock on Earth.
The time interval measured by an observer who sees the two events occur at the same location.
The time it takes for light to travel one meter.
Time that has been corrected for gravitational errors.
questions.explanation: Proper time: time interval measured in frame where events occur at same spatial location. Shortest possible time between events. Example: wristwatch measures proper time of wearer. For moving clock: $\Delta t = \gamma\Delta t_0$, where $\gamma > 1$.

questions.question: As an object's velocity ($v$) approaches the speed of light ($c$), what happens to the time interval ($\Delta t$) measured by a stationary observer?
options: It stays exactly the same as $\Delta t_0$.
It approaches infinity (time appears to nearly stop for the moving object).
It becomes negative, meaning the object moves backward in time.
questions.explanation: $\Delta t = \gamma\Delta t_0 = \Delta t_0/\sqrt{1-v^2/c^2}$. As $v \to c$, $\gamma \to \infty$, $\Delta t \to \infty$. Time appears frozen for light-speed objects. For $v=0.99c$: $\gamma=7.09$; $v=0.999c$: $\gamma=22.4$.

questions.question: In the 'Twin Paradox,' one twin stays on Earth while the other travels to a star at $0.9c$ and returns. When they reunite:
options: They are exactly the same age.
The traveling twin has turned into pure energy.
questions.explanation: Traveling twin undergoes acceleration (turnaround) → not always in inertial frame → breaks symmetry. For $v=0.9c$ ($\gamma=2.29$), 10-year round trip for traveler = 22.9 years on Earth. Traveler ages less. Verified with atomic clocks on airplanes.

questions.question: Which real-world technology must account for time dilation to remain accurate?
questions.explanation: GPS satellites: 1) Special relativity: moving at 3.87 km/s → clocks slow by ~7 μs/day, 2) General relativity: weaker gravity → clocks fast by ~45 μs/day. Net: ~38 μs/day fast. Without correction: position errors ~10 km/day accumulating.

questions.question: Muons are subatomic particles with a very short lifespan. How do they reach the Earth's surface from the upper atmosphere despite their short life?
options: They travel faster than the speed of light.
Their 'internal clock' slows down due to their high speed, allowing them to live longer from our perspective.
They are constantly regenerated by air molecules.
questions.explanation: Muons: created at ~15 km altitude, mean lifetime at rest = 2.2 μs. Even at $c$, would decay in ~660 m. But moving at ~0.995c ($\gamma≈10$), lifetime extended to ~22 μs → travel ~6.6 km. Many reach surface. Direct experimental proof.

questions.question: If you are on a spaceship moving at $0.99c$, how does your own heart rate feel to you?
questions.explanation: In your own rest frame, you're stationary. Time dilation affects how others see you, not your own experience. Biological processes, clocks, aging proceed normally in own frame. Only relative motion matters.

questions.question: The 'Lorentz Factor' ($\gamma$) is used to calculate the degree of dilation. What is the value of $\gamma$ when $v = 0$?
According to a stationary observer, a moving clock:
questions.explanation: Moving clocks run slow (time dilation). Example: $v=0.5c$, $\gamma=1.155$ → 1 second on moving clock = 1.155 seconds on stationary clock. Verified by: 1) Airplane atomic clocks, 2) Muon decay, 3) Particle accelerator lifetimes.

questions.question: If an astronaut travels for 1 year of their time at a speed where $\gamma = 2$, how much time has passed on Earth?
questions.explanation: $\Delta t = \gamma\Delta t_0 = 2 \times 1\ \text{year} = 2\ \text{years}$. Requires $v = \sqrt{3}/2 c ≈ 0.866c$. For traveler: ages 1 year, Earth: ages 2 years. Space travel consequence: 'time gain' for traveler.

questions.question: Time dilation is a 'symmetric' effect between two inertial observers. This means:
options: Only one person is actually moving.
Both observers see the other's clock running slow.
Time dilation only happens in one direction.
Time dilation doesn't exist if both people are moving.
questions.explanation: Symmetry: each inertial observer sees other's clock running slow. Resolved by relativity of simultaneity: they disagree on 'now'. Paradoxical but consistent. Broken in twin paradox due to acceleration (non-inertial segment).

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! Mastery of time dilation including proper time definition, Lorentz factor calculations, twin paradox resolution, experimental evidence (muons, GPS), and symmetrical nature of relativistic effects.
scoreMessages.70: Very good! Strong understanding of time dilation. Review: 1) Proper time vs. dilated time, 2) $\gamma$ factor calculations and limits, 3) Twin paradox explanation, 4) Experimental evidence examples, 5) Symmetry and observer perspectives.
scoreMessages.50: Fair. Focus on: 1) Proper time definition (events at same location), 2) Time dilation formula $\Delta t = \gamma\Delta t_0$, 3) Twin paradox outcome and why, 4) Real-world examples (GPS, muons), 5) How dilation appears to different observers.
scoreMessages.0: Start with basics: Review how constant speed of light leads to time dilation, the meaning of proper time, and why moving clocks run slow from a stationary observer's perspective.
